element_texts.text:
Clinton Illinois June 15, 1891
Dear Peoples All,
When I came in from Weldon 12 miles East Saturday afternoon and went to the P.O. and asked for letters, the little post mistress handed me among others the great fat juicy family letters.  I always feel like throwing up my hat when I see it.  It does me more good than a square meal and a bath.  May she never grow thinner.  I don't believe you can any of you enjoy it so much as I do.  Last summer up in the Rockies and here in Illinois.  Pater has a right to enjoy it surely- Washington 
Gladden must be queer I never heard him but once, that was upon prayer and he was good.  It don't seem possible that Elyria can have electric lights.  As I remember Elyria it is about as pretty a place as there is in the U.S. The lights must make it beautiful in the evening.  I rec'd a fine letter from Mother, this morning I felt justified for going to the post office on Sunday when I found it. It's always a treat if it is a rare one Chas!  Your name is not Dennis.  Never, never, never- This last circulator has no word

from Mary - and [[unclear] seems to have lost his voice - I suppose his Commencement Oration takes his time.  Oh, unclear.  Get there.  "The genus of literature are all less than 4 minutes long"  Prof unclear.  To the All There That Hist. Society I would say there are no Jackrabbits here but the fields seem to be full of rabbits.   They are very tame too. I have seen half a dozen in a group together sit by a hedge at the roadside and watch a team drive by without winking. The quails keep up a continual Bob-White and often let you come within 10 ft of them. They are thick and tame. I often see birds and flowers. I don't know, but I can't stop to look at them.  I usually breakfast at 6, sometimes when I stay over night with a farmer I get routed out at about 5 - I stayed overnight with a man named Totten only hous miles from Monticello - His wife was a very nice, sweet faced little bit of a woman and they had 4 boys smart keen eyed clean looking, oldest about 16 and youngest about 5 y. They were jolly. I had so much fun with them it almost made me homesick to see my own big and little brothers. They had a big strawberry short kake (long) with so many berries in it you could hardly find the short kake and rich. Oh and apple butter and peach butter and preserved pears unclear.  Some of these farmers live well or else they throw on lots of style when they have company. The little Totten kid had a ha-ha-ha laugh on him that he nearly killed me. He goes to school with his brothers. He was so lonesome alone they had to let him go.

2.  Y.M.C.A.
I wish I could go to the Strawberry and Ice cream festival in Elyria and see the people. See how many or how few I knew -  Mr. Birdsall is a unclear. The last two sundays there I have not been to S.S. - I feel lost, but I had so much writing to do I could not? do it. Going to try to go next week. Childrens services in the Presb. Ch. today. Brandon and I went. They had the "Little Builders" on the platform. A boys and girls missionary society like "Kuige Missionaries" about 30 of them - Toward the close the Supt. of the S.S. got up to make a speach and he turned and faced the little kids and said " It's a little late but I want to say one thing - I want to tell how I saw unclear unclear a lot of children."  Just then a big beatle began to hover just over the heads of the children.  They snickered and snached at the beatle and paid no attention to him - He gave up in despair and said "We will sing the closing hymn."  I wished I was in the Cong. Ch. at Elyria Ohio - I would give a good deal to hear Gertrude Stanley's oration. I think she is one of the people if she is red-haired - in fact to be very much prejudiced in favor of red haired people - girls unclear especially -
Mr Afariah? writes a fine letter where he began by saying he has nothing to say. I expect to make enough this summer to supply the place of of Mr Spear as a benefactor to Oberlin. Keep your purse open. I shall probably benefit here in the first place by staying away though. Good for Jack. Pat him on the back. When troubles crack . . we shall never lack - give hime a smack for me.

That right Statte  Stand up for Oberlin - to the latter end - Jorii Society of course Nette and go where you please - Miss Bullard told me that Aetioran was the best Society. I think one is about the same as the other but I never attended either. Nette take my racket and get it restrung. It's a very firm frame and Carol Churchill will string it for $1.00 I think. Go in and win.
In what respect have the N.Y. Presb.'s put their foot into Dr Brigg's case? John? What should they have done? I would like to see Mrs. Richardson and her kids and that young lady called May Crisies. John and Carrie and unclear and Mary seem to be a good many more uncles and aunts than the rest of us. Its hardly fair.
Well, my business is picking up a little. I made $18.00 last week. Expenses probably $9.00 or $10.00 - hope to do better this week. We have made a good start here. Some of the people have ordered goods and from them we get good unclear always. Then the F.M.B.A.men at Welden wrote to their State Sec'y - N.E. Robinson at Chicago in regard to the N.D.A. and he gave it a good send off so we shall get them almost to a man.
It is after 10. I must to bed. There is a hard week work ahead of me. You may think its fun but it is not entirely so I assure you. God bless you all and keep you.
Sincerely Harl.

June 1897
205 Ridgewood Ave.
Min. Min
My Dear Pater
You will perhaps be surprised to hear from me here- it was such a forlorn hope that brought me hear that I would not speak of it for fear it should come to nothing. But it came
out so far beyond my

tonight and will write again soon - Time is very precious just now and you will  forgive my not writing more fui sure.

Please tell only the family. I am sure I love you all every-one more  and not less - So God bless you all. Good bye- Harl 

Perhaps you think I'm not happy?

Expectations that I have not had time to write before. Rena Goldebury has promised to be my wife. You may remember her, she has been at the house several times. You and the rest know about her and shall hear and see much more. I am going to go D.W.

Chicago Theol. Sem., 81 Ashland Boul. Room 223
Jan. 13th 1891
Dear Mr. Root and Annie & Francis & every one else -- I am so sorry not to have seen Mr. Root. I was out to Oak Park. Spent the Sunday with the Lowes' -- Pauline & Frank Lowe's Father & Mother. I got home Monday a.m. at 8-15, found Mr. Root's card & went at once to the Palmer House but could not find you there. I had a vocal lesson at 9 after that I came home & found LeGrand Smith & heard about your being here nearly all day Sunday -- It made me hot.

I went to dinner at about 11.30 then went down to Palmer House & hunted for your names again this time I discovered that there are two Hotel register books there & I had not looked at the right one before - I found your names but the clerk said you had paid your bill & gone - I was glad to here that you had paid your bill but I didn't know where to look for you there. I went around to the unclear Depot 4 times the last time just as the 3-10 train was pulling out but I could not find you.
If G.L. had got a key from the janitor & got into my room, you could have found in my address book Edith's address & every one's else.

2.
of the younger generation of Oberlin people here -
I had a spended time out to Oak Park but it makes me hot to think of yours waiting here Sunday night. It is too bad.
I called Saturday Evening on Mr. & Mrs. "Keep" Patton and Sunday afternoon on Mrs. Margaret Rankin Dunlop who was the intimate friend of Mrs. W. Metcalf and of Miss McClure & met her 3 sisters her husband & her two children a boy & girl. Sam and Hannah. Sam is only about 4 yrs old but he weighs about 60 lbs. & he is a chunk I tell you, Stuart too.

It is called "Saints' Rest."
Oak Park is full of nice people They claim 18 students in Oberlin more than go from there to any other school. There are about 80 altogether away in different colleges - The [[Saul's[] are of the nicest too. There is among the Cong. people a society recently organized called the "Christian Steward's League." They are all pledged to give at least 1/10th of their income to Charitable purposes. It is "a society for the promotion of Proportionate Giving"
Mr. [[Saue[] said to me "We do not care to have this advertised but we think it is going to grow."
The Lowe's have 6 children 2 are in O. one older boy is in

DePaul and at home are Albert about 15, Florence 12 & George 5 + - I had a great time with them I tell you, along with Sam Dunlop.
Dr. Hoyt would make a good Pres. for Oberlin but the people who almost worship him, would not let him go.
I am going to try to get the tenor position in that Church if I don't get Union Park Choir. I am going out every night this week to Warren Ave. Cong Church to sing at their continued week of prayer meetings-
I like Mr. Adams the pastor there much. It is a nice

church too, lots of good young people. Y.P.S.C.E. 130 members. I met out there two cousins of the Harrison girl named Vanderelia . The girl looks like unclear Harrison and the boy some like Chas.
They were very cordial to me.
The next time you come to this village let me know beforehand and I won't go off and stay over Sunday -
Sincerely yours
Harl
Remember me to Net & Hal & Jack & Carrie & any of my friends if such should inquire of me.
Harl

I feel that I must say something to you dear Nettie, I do want so much to see you happy, I want you to become so now, and I have been thinking that perhaps a little experience of my own might help you.  When I was about Harrys age a number of my school friends became Christians.  I felt that I wanted to be a Christian too, but I could not feel that I was.  I thought - there must be a great change, and so I was unhappy and troubled for about 24 months waiting for the change that would not come.  At last some one told me that I could never become a Christian that way, I must come just as I was.  With some people this is never much change, I must do as Christ bids us, "Come to me and I will give you rest."
I did just that and all the trouble fled.  I was happy, & Nettie, you can not

begin to think what a comfort it is to just give up your will and see Christ's to do his will.  The trouble with me was that I wanted to come to Christ my way.  I wanted a great change.  The time to grow in grace is after we take Jesus as our leader.
Nettie we do want you to be a Christian, won't you make up your own mind now,  wont grieve the Holy Spirit away.  Now is the day of salvation.  We are all praying for you to come into the light.  We want you to have a share in our happiness, the only true happiness there is.  
Yours with love
Mother

My Dearly beloved Nette
I had thought of having a little talk with you some night, but you are busy as so many around that it is not convenient.  I have something to tell you which will not be pleasant for you to hear, but as you are at home I feel that I want to tell you first of any.  It is more comfortable to hear things right first-hand, I had hoped that owing to my health which will probably never be much improved, that God would not send me any more little ones, to be a care and a burden to the others for so much care will naturally fall on thin shoulders, but he in his wisdom which we do not understand has ordered things differently and if I live and keep comfortable till the last of April then will, 'God willing', be

another little stranger to love and care for.  If I had my health I could welcome the small one more but- I do be full sorry to have added burdens put up on you.  If all goes well we hope to send you to Oberlin next Sept;  You know I have used my heart up and it has to a great extent failed me but if I am careful of my general health it may continue to do its work for many years.  I do want to live and take care of your father for he will need all our care as the years go by.  Now my very dear do not let this make you unhappy at-all, I tell you now so that you will not hear it first from outsiders.  I wish exceedingly that the newcomer may be a little girl to take your place when you are away.  This is long enough.
Yours with much love,
Mother

Elyria, April 29, 1883.

Dear Marion
It is a lovely day though some what cool.  Many thanks for your very good letter.  It was very acceptable.  We have Annie and John with us to-day which is very pleasant;  Seven of family attended church.  I had to teach Ed Martins class.  It is a class of boys average age of some about ten or twelve years, and such a class.  Harl says they talked so saucy to Mr. ((M)) that he has given up the class.  It is a very mischievous class, do you remember Willie Marshall the little coloured boy that the children call unclear.  He was one.  
Harry Wright, Jacob Smieden, Carl Rienhart, and four or five more.  It requires a brisk talker to get in many words, the boys talk so much.  I like them, they are real bright.  Mrs Bunkins class is the one that S.I.A Williams had.  Mr ((unclear)) is in Boston, Mrs Parker has not taught a class since last fall, neither Mr P or MRs V stay so S.S Mr. Herman Ely taught Mr Day's class today as Mr Day stays with his father most of

time.  His father is very feeble.  Minnie Garford expects to be sick before many months.  Ethel says Mrs Haines is to take the class till July, but I think she will keep it longer.  Of course you will have a class when you come.  Mr Mclean does have a hard time getting teachers.  I think it is really more impolite to refuse to teach a class when he asks.  I did go to the Missionary meeting connected with the Conference, Anna Rich, Sarah, Mrs Charley Johson, Mrs Roslin Cary and myself from Elyria, Mrs. Halch of Oberlin and Mrs Lukins of E.Cleveland went over in the street car together.  We all depended upon Mrs Lukins who knew where the 1st Church is  located, but she was so busy talking to Mrs ((Hatch)) that she did not notice the church and  we went to the end of the Detroit Street railroad which is about two miles beyond the church. You can imagin what a good laugh we had. As we went on the early train, we reached the church in time. The meeting was good, some of the reports were good.  Mrs.Prof Jewett had a very sicy paper, and Miss unclear of unclear Turkey, was not only a very sweet looking lady, but a pleasant speaker also.  Have you heard her. We only staid till 3.30

The 'Young Ladies' Missionary Band is rather a peculiar institution.  Mrs McLean was wanted as president and she said she would accept-on condition that all the married ladies would join the other society.  It is thought-by many if that change could be made many of the young girls like most in Aunt-Anna's class and Mrs. Markhams class could be prevailed upon to join the Y.L's society and that-class of girls ought to be at work.  
The change has not been made, but many of the members are coming into our society.  The young ladies unite with the "House Missionary Society" this week, The Young Peoples; also had an entertainment a week or so ago for the benefit of the Flower Mission.  It was a rainy night and but few people went.  I think they made about $11.00.
As usual I have had so much help from small people that I really little idea of what I have said.  I would like some little things from Boston but - 'will tell you, some week day.  With much love and best wishes,
Yours
The Mother

Elyria, September 23rd, 1889
Dear Marion
This is a beautiful day though a cool wind.  I walked down to church for the first-time in months.  Ethel staid with -Keyes Dewitt or Percy Dewitt, which is the better?  
Nette came home yesterday completely used up, so much so that many tears fell and dire threats of never going to Oberlin again.
Wednesday I intended to find time to write yesterday PM

but as I knew A.S had written I did not think it absolutely essential & I slept instead.
Ethel, Nette, Keyes & I went over to Oberlin Monday P.M  Nette was too sick to go in the morning.  We went with old Kit as Nette felt she could do no walking.
She decided to stay at Anna's Monday night.  We found Anna apparently well.  Ethel and I only staid an hour or so reaching home about six o'clock. Yesterday evening just at 7:10 43 West Ave, time, a telegram came from Oberlin saying Come on early train.  The message boy

2

said the train was a little late and we might possibly catch it:  the horse was harnessed while I put on a dress, and away we trotted.  The train was at the depot and I boarded the first car which was a smoker and found a seat after passing through a couple of cars.
Reached O shortly, and found a small boy awaiting me.  He came about the time we received the telegram.  Mrs Chamberlain was asking him for which I was extremely thankful.  Mrs Lewis a lady who keeps roomers and where Mr. Root rroomed for years was helping the Dr. unclear  She left as soon as she saw me.  The Dr. very soon

and Mrs Chamberlain to get her children ready for school, Mrs Hoffner is at ((Tutor)) Martin's.  Their baby which was expected the first of the month never came till last Friday and  Mrs. Martin has a fever and so Mrs. Hoffner could not come to Anna. Anna engaged her for the 6th Oct.  They could find no other nurse.  Mrs Savage just came to our house yesterday.  She was sent for to wash and dress Keyes when I went away. So I had Harl telegraph to your father to drive over with Mrs Savage if she would could, they reached Oberlin about eleven o'clock.  I hope

3

she will be able to stay until Mrs Hofner can come.  Father and I came home as soon as I had shown her round the house so we went back home at one o'clock.  Is this not quite a story.  Ethel has gone down to the post-office now, as we hope to hear on the 1.30 train.
The joke is that Nette should be there after all.  She had to go to Mrs Johnson's for breakfast but was up to see the baby in the fore noon.
She said Sunday that if she could only go to Nan's she thought she could get her lessons but she knew she could not if she staid at Mrs Johnson's. Anna helped

her in Greek Monday night and told her she would read yesterday's lesson with her yesterday morning but of course I would not let her.  
Anna was sick from 2.30AM to 7AM.  She was pretty sick but very bright and happy after it was over.  Very tired though and I am anxious to hear.  She heeded sleep but could not get it before we left.  The small Root is as yet not remarkable for beauty and considerable black hair grows on the top of his head.  Augustus, Lucy Marguerite and Edith started west yesterday. Will and Mayne go soon and E.M. and wife to unclear We are to have old unclear after

4

they go,  Then I can go to O and take Anna  to ride when she is able.  
Nette has her hair cut as she thought she would have more time to study if she did not-have to fix hair so much.  
I hope Ethel will come back before the post man as I want to tell you if news comes from Oberlin.
Do you see Nette Cary often. She is very homesick I hear.  I am sorry for her. I think Nette unclear spent a good share of her time in tears last weeks.  Postal just here will copy. 
"Anna & baby doing nicely, exact weight of baby 7 1/4 lbs, expect milk fever this afternoon A.S.R

such a scribble as I have but I will send it along.  Harry is about to go to work
Hastily very
Mother

My Dear Children A & A
We were very sorry when we received word today that you could not be with us tomorrow.  I understand you to say that this was the week you could come and Nette was sure too. We had a quarter of beef the first of the week, the most of it-we salted, but our big roast-we saved to eat cold to morrow.  We cooked it so as to have it cold with hot potatoes and gravy, pickled pears pumpkins and mince pies.  It is so good, and I am dreadfully disappointed not to have you to eat there of.  I know you would come if you could.  Come next Sunday even if we can not feed you as well.  I do want to see you.  Ethel will do nicely and feel more comfortable to have you not treat her as a boarder, but as one of you, that is as though

she was at home.  She has said nothing, but I know she wants you to feel that you are not confined at home on her account.  She has said that she thinks her room is lovely and everything, but she does not want to tie you at home.
We scolded her because she thought that Anna could come without Azariah, wait till she is married and has a house of her own.  She will see things very differently then.  We want you both when either of you come.  You were right Anna stand by your husband every time.  I am with you.  Come as soon as ever you can.  How would you like to have Nette come over and stay with Ethel when you come home.  I just thought of it.
You had better vote for Harrison Tuesday, but I suppose that would be against your principles.  I believe in standing up for your principles.  I wish we thought alike, but everything will come out right in the end.  Come, Come, Come.  Yours with love, Mother

My Dear Anna.
Will you try to find out what those Oberlin children need that costs little and which will be proper for a New Year's present.  How are you, and how do you do.
My letter must close. Has the toe recovered?  Yours with love.
Mother
The four small boys have made out their lists.

Dear Anna
I am very glad you told us how you feel, and hope you will always do so, as it will make us all happier.  I think I know that you want to be a Christian, and that you feel that you cannot do anything of yourself.  Have you been trying in your own strength or have you truly) cast all your care on Jesus and left all for him to do?  If you go to Jesus, and ask him to make you a Christian you know he will because he says - "Ask and you shall receive." and then try to please Jesus in every little thing you do - do all for Him & I think you will have evidence that you love him.  Work, play, study, conquer your temper for his sake - Do this now and then do it every day of your life.  But only safety is in going to God always-keeping with Him.  Then we shall go right & be happy.
Mother

My dear Anna,
Just think of us poor forlorn people just ready to sit down to the table, no Marion, no Anna, no John.  It is certainly much lonesome without you all.  I sent by John a napkin and ring, a shirt, and a pair of slidings for you, he wanted something with which he could fill his trunk.  I am sorry that Mrs Holmes is detained. I hope you will hear good news from her soon.  Nothing from Marion but a postal.  I fear she intends to retaliate. I mean to write her soon.  No news, children as full as ever, at present Mayo stands here reading me.  There

goes the dinner bell.
Yours with love,
Mother 
Remember me to Maggie
The above undated production was doubtless marked at
Elyria, Ohio, Tues, Sept 12th 1883
Dear Darter
I have written to you once today a tiresomely long and prosy epistle. And there appears no need of adding hereto.
I might specify that a pic nic at the lake is expected tomorrow or next day.. Mrs O. Root's  pic nic to which Mr & Mrs J.J

Metcalf were invited - and Mrs M will probably attend.  Mrs M being unavoidably detained therefrom.
I have also -(another item)-reason to suppose that Mr & Mrs H.E. Brooks of Cleveland is now at the house, having lately, this afternoon, arrived there.  I expected they might come yesterday,  H.E.B to make figures and bid upon our new school house.  Bids to be opened tomorrow. He has not much time to make his figures.
Our house seems remarkably empty.  I guess here is room enough for visitors.
Respetfully and ancestrally.

((unclear)) 13th,  This letter was not mailed yesterday thinking it might hurt your ((phelinks?)) to get two so important letters in one day.  Mrs M: with her three sisters & two of their husbands, besides Ralph and several 4 of his cousins have gone to the pic nic Lake today.  Geo. P Wright the farmer, his son, 14 years old run over by the car today, both legs cut off. Mr & Mrs Brooks went home last night. unclear

Jan 24, 1883
My dear Anna,
We were much pleased to hear from you tonight, but very sorry to hear that Blanche is ill, and you not well.  You must have something to strengthen you as you are sick so often.  I will see the Dr for you, don't worry about it.  I think the cause is that you are working too hard and are troubled about the sicknesses of your friends.  I want to see you, you don't know how we miss you.  It would seem that we might get used to you being from home but I think the desire to have you at home grows upon me.  We are fully well and happy.  Baby walks very well, has given up creeping.  Mayo falls down so much that it calls forth this remark from his lips nearly every time he falls "I tumble down that" "I can't stan up, no!"  It sounds very funny we think.  Every morning he crawls over into our bed and says "Here come papa

boy food."  Nettie puts him to sleep nights.  She is very patient and good to him.  You know how Ralph and he used to quarrel I was very much discouraged about them and greatly troubled.  Since Esther went away they play together very nicely and quarrel very little in comparison with what they used.  I wish you could have some of our beef steak it would do you good.  You must not work so hard and don't trouble about things, won't do any copying or any other work more than absolutely necessary.  Be sure and take some out door exercise not-lazy walks.  I have just scribbled this off in much haste but I think it can be deciphered with patience and perseverance.
If you can, come home Saturday.
With very much love
Mother
Do you really have good nourishing food;  Do you have milk?  Drink all the milk you can, it is good for you, very.
You are the one who ought to have gone to a better boarding place better than John, thanks for your long letter.  Write often of not so much.  I am afraid you do not eat fish enough.
Father

Feb, 18 1883
My dear Anna,-
A telegram reached us today stating your reasons for not coming home.  We heard last night that the train had not left Freemont at nine o'clock.  We were much disappointed and hoped against hope that you would come even if the train was late.  You must try again next Sat. and come during the day.   Don't depend on evening trains.  You poor girls have had a hard time this past week.  You have been in my thoughts very much and I felt so sorry for you in your loneliness.  I can not express my thoughts in words.  It is a consolation to feel that the dear our gone hour has escaped so much sorrow and trouble in this world, but-it is very hard for the poor father and mother.  Was she their only one?
There is so much sickness here and some have gone to their long home.  Cassius Mountain is to buried tomorrow.  Mrs John N Bullock died yesterday and Old Capt. ((Suckins)) who lives on the fair ground is

not expected to live.  Three of our neighbors, Mrs King, Miss Nevins and Mr, Reed have been sick in bed during the week.  We are all improved and happy, there were but four of us to sit up in the church this morning, but we hope for more another Sunday.  I dread to take Ralph to church for fear he will be restless, he wants to go much.  Baby is quite funny and bothers the boys as much as ever.  He is crazy to get out doors.
How is your general health?  You ought to have more of that medicine.  I should have been out to see you last week had there been any certainty of getting back the same day.  Take good care of yourself and don't work too hard.  Do you read your essay, tomorrow?  I wish I could write you a nicer letter but letter writing is no more my forte than is talking but I can feel for people and love them much.  With love to Miss Howes and Maggie and a double portion for yourself I must say good night.
Mother
Be sure and come Sat.  We can sleep three of you and shall be very glad to see Miss Howes and Maggie too.  Bring them along.  It will do them good to get a taste of our noisy house-hold.  If the noise gets unendurable we can put them in the parlor, I mean the girls.

June 13, 1883,
Dear Anna
I have just sent you a note by Sarah Root, now I will write and explain what I wrote in the note.  Of course it is impossible to get a competent girl for two months and if Miss Bell is teachable I should greatly prefer to teaching her instead of a raw dutch girl who would not appreciate the trouble taken.  I hope Miss Bell is a good ironer, and I do want her.  I wonder how soon she could come if she will.  Will she want to be there till July 4th.  I suppose ((unclear)) wants to go as soon as possible.  Miss Savage very much wants you to come home Sat. afternoon.  Your dress is all done but trying it on and stitching some  of the bands tight.
I have been intending to write you for a long time and tell you something. Perhaps Marion has told you. I wrote to her a long time ago and the dear good girl wrote me a beautiful letter, Marion is indeed one

of the 'salt of the Earth'. I have felt that- to tell either of you would he go spoil your pleasure for the sum men. But I want you to know, I want you girls to have a nice time and I aid so much want. To full will and shiny, instead of sick and cross, I have almost been rebellious and wielded in thought. I think there is no danger of any thing serious happening, till after your return to college.
Now my girl don't let this trouble you. I shall do my very best so that you can have a pleasant Summer. And though I know it will be very hard to be pleasant and even tempered as I should, I will try with God's help to be decently pleasant. Come far, can you?
Yours with much love, 
Mother.

Elyria, Ohio Apr. 20th 1883
Dear Anna
I tore open your letter without noticing that it was directed to Mother. But I took pains to pacify her for the impoliteness by telling her that an old home by old maid school marm became a cross step mother could not always get so nice letters as that. What remarks some people always make. Can not you come home some day this week and stay till the 4.42 train goes? I will go down street with you or meet you at the depot

if you desire, and go with you while you a a hat. I think you deserve a good one and I am afraid if you go alone you will deny yourself more than is necessary. I don't think I told you that I had a nice letter from Frank Johnson Sat. night. Ralph is not well enough to come home yet. They hope he can come about Christmas. Mrs. Johnson is getting tired of prairie life. The H.S. children Harl, Ethel, and Harry have not covered themselves with as much glory in examinaitons as usual. Harl stood very low in Latin 55% I believe. None of the others failed in anything but they did not do as well as usual. Nettie has

good marks. I must write a private letter to May. I will tell you when you come. I wish your hickory nuts were here and we would crack them for you. I think John will divide the apples. I want to come and see you, but could stay but a little while on account of baby.
With much love, 
Mother

November 11th, 1883.
My Anna Dear, 
How the winds do blow. It makes me shiver. I am so glad none of our family are out on the waters. It has been a lovely day. I went to church for the first time since July. It seemed good to be there and I wanted to stay to S. S. but found I was tired when I reached home. We missed you and John today. How I wish you could be at home more, but perhaps you can come next Saturday. Please tell Miss Howes that I am very sorry I was not at home when she

called. If she was over to Reachers'? ex. (as Anna Rich seems to think) please say to her I feel like scolding because she did not come to dinner. We are all in usual health. Ralph went to S. S. and remembered his lesson well. unclear Nettie was requested to do something and did not start promptly. Ralph said to her "Nettie! Behold, to obey is better than sacrifier." We are all as full of noise and confusion as ever, but we do have some good times. I have written a long letter to Marion so you must take a short one. Are you feeling real well? Don't do too much. Have you put on thick flannels? Do you take care of your fire? Don't sit in a cold room,

Just spend time to take good care of yourself. Remember good health is needed in order to use the knowledge you obtain. Then I have given some advice. I think I will bid you a very good night. With very much love, Mother. Marian's friends, Mr. and Mrs. Ponderer of Nation Mass. were here Friday. Did not come to our home. We went to Dr Dr Wills to meet them at dinner but they were delayed missing R. R. connections, and did not get here to dinner. They were at Uncle Eliab's to tea and we went over and spent the evening there. I recognized in Mrs. Pelouber a little Connie Thaxter girl I remembered in Bangor some 40 years ago. Father

Elyria, Dec. 15, 1883.
My dear Anna, 
Your letter received last evening. I am sorry you are troubled and want to help you very much. I don't think about rides as I do about presents, not exactly. Though I object to much riding especially when a lady is ready to go with any man, not always a gentleman that asks her. Your case is different. You know Mr. R. to be a gentleman and you have accepted is company to other places. Now he asks the privilege of coming to your own house and take you to ride. I think you can not refuse his request without

being impolite. He is John's friend as well as yours. It will be all right to to with him.  I wrote you a long letter last night, but thinking it over today decided not to send it as you are very busy just now and some things I said might trun your thoughts from your work.  I want to have a good talk with you soon. Don't forget to bring Miss Bell when you come.  I am glad to have Ethel with you and how much I do wish she were a Christian. It seems as though I could not have it other-wise. There is the making of a grand woman in her if she will only come out for Christ. May God bless, keep and direct you aright.

With a heart full of love for you. Mother
Children improving in temper.

184
Annie my Dear, I am very glad you are will to tell me all your troubles and trials, and I wish I could help you more. But you must not let your self worry. It will not do. I know that now, as your life has been among books that you have but little practical knowledge as compared with many of your age, but with your book knowledge, you will find that the knowledge of other things will be easier for you to gain when you really get started. When you are through college things will look different to you and a few months will give you a good sart in house hold matters unclear.

Now don't say where you read this, I can't do it, she don't know me unclear. I do know. I know that six years ago, I would have no more thought that I could do the things I can do now, unclear you think you can make a dress.  When you want to do things to please others, you can do them. It has not bee necessary for you to make bread, wash, iron and sew much as yet. Your business has been to get book knowledge. Now comes the other things which you can conquer, when you undertake. Don't think about then till next July.  You must not. It is not good for you actually morally or physically.  It is foolish. There my dear I can't afford to scold you any more. With a very great deal of love 
Mother

Elyria June 18, 1884
My Annie dear,
Thank you I am better to day. I hope better than I have been for two weeks. I am weak. I said in bed yesterday but am dressed to day and lying on the bed. I was better in part yesterday than Monday but the Dr thought it best for me to keep still and I felt very much like it.
Sarah is afraid you thought she was impolite MOnday when she appeared at the parlor door. She did not know Mr. Root was here and she was looking for you. She was quite troubled

I hope your essay is done and handed in. Don't try to cocme home to morrow  you are all tired. The father is trying to off with out this so good tip
Much very love, Mother
You and John are really headed at home on the Strawberry short cake account.  Some of them are getting a little "Cloyed". Now I consider it you are not very valuable as that line yourself You need not come but send John whenever you can. Sincerely Father.

June 20, 1884
My dear Anna-
I just happened to think as I lay here on the North End of veranda that I had better write now, for fear I should not have time after your father came.  I am better, but the Dr does not want me to sit up, but he is coming this afternoon and I hope he will say I am well enough to do so.  He told me yesterday that I must have patience and all would be right he thought, or hoped.
Sarah spends her fore noons with me as she is not good? I find that people are good. I put as though I was a fraud lying here in this style.  Lou is doing as well as she can

under the heat unclear
It is so very warm that it drives my poor wits astray.  I can think of nothing to write of interest so I think I will stop.  I hope to hear from you this P.M
With much love
Mother
It is very warm.
The cow gone lost this morning, but was reclaimed before noon.  Marion Metcalf is expected tomorrow.  Other news is scarce.
Respectfully 
Father

Babies all asleep, October 27, 7.10 PM 11 East Ave   Elyria, Ohio
Dear Annie,-
We as one united family have a grave accusation to bring against YOU, Anna Mayo Stevens Metcalf.  You are guilty of the grave misdemeanor of stealing the heart of Isaac Stevens Metcalf Jun, and we have been tyrannized over by the young child all day.  You never beheld him when he behaved as he has today.  He has mourned for you all day and would not be comforted.  He slept from 10.30AM & 12.15PM, and howled for you the rest of the time.  It was really funny to see him look for you when he heard a foot-

step and the looks of disappointment which spread over his countenance when it was not you.  Now we desire you not to return till we have gained the heart of this little child.  Anna Rich did well, so she said, especially with the beginners.
Ralph wanted me to tell you that he stored 100 in Reading and was one of the four best writers.  It has rained most of the day so Maggie could not dry all her clothes.
We succeeded well.  Ella had my room swept before noon and I took a nap while baby slept.
Have the best time you can and sleep just as much as you can.  Baby will forget about you somewhat and behave better tomorrow.
With much love, Mother

June 26, '86 Saturday P.M.
My much beloved Anna-
We are glad to hear that you are having a good time.  We are getting along well, and want you not to worry about home and home things.  Allie has just finished the mending.   For dinner we had beef-steak, peas & raspberries.  I get deserts the easiest way.  Yesterday for dinner, we had nothing but potatoes al la cream & raspberry short-cake.
I sent over four loaves brown bread, had no white bread as it was not needed.  We also let the Association have 3 qts milk so I guess we did our share.
We all had a good time but

missed the absent ones.
Baby wrote you a letter by I fear it will not reach you.  I have slept more than an hour this PM and Marion is now sleeping I think.  Nettie is very good and helpful, we miss you because we love you and like to have you around but we want you to sleep and really rest.
Mother
Dad - I know this writing is most miserable, yes!

1887
My dear Annie,
Your letter just received and we have done some scolding.  We had invited Paul Thayer, hoping that you & Azariah would be here to help entertain him.  I am afraid he will not have a good time.  Ethel does not expect to come to stay over Sunday.
Harriet has an idea that nothing can be done very well here without "Annie." They will get along someway , Harlan will doubtless come over.  All Well. Father.

May 9th 1887
My dear Annie,
We had an unexpected visit from Harl & Ethel tonight.  They have gone to the Baptist concert this evening.  I went down to committee meeting this afternoon.  Refreshment Committee.  I do not expect to do any work, only make a cake.  Mayo is getting along well.  He coughs much and very hard.  Was in bed two days.  He has been just as good and patient as can be.  I never saw a better child.  Perfectly trustworthy & obedient.  Our children are

a queer set. To a casual observer they appear only impudent and disobedient but there is some good in them after all.  I think Mayo is better when sick than any of the rest will be.  They show no signs as yet, but I shall expect to have them sick any day now.  I did want to go Thursday evening but if they are sick I cannot.  I hardly think it would be fair for you to come over and not go to the roll car.  I rode with the Father up to Carlisle this morning.  Eliab and Isaac Jr, went with us.  Just after we started Ely pitched out head first into the mud between the wheels

2
She is trying hard to fill your peace.  She went to Y.P, meeting last-night-and I went to evening services so as to come home with her.  I have not been to evening service before in months.  I did not go to church in the morning.  We appreciate your cordial invitations to your home and would gladly accept them were it convenient but perhaps sometime in the future we shall get there.  Azariah makes an accusation against you thus early.  He says you do not take enough rest.  This will not do.  You were too tired to begin, and you must sleep and rest.  How do the stairs seem?  It is hard on callers to climb them, Can you not entertain them

We suppose that the wheel went over him and I held my breath but he screamed and stood up so we knew his back was not broken.  His hat was covered with mud also one of his hands.  His face scratched a little.  To night when we undressed him we found two marks or bruises on his arms & a big patch of mud on his back.  He says the wheel went over his arm.  He felt very much ashamed.  Ely & Ba- sleep together since Mayo is sick.  Ely wants to undress when Ba-does, so the latter goes to bed in our bed, but he has to play about one hour or more first before sleep.  Ely goes to sleep very quickly.  Tonight Mayo went to bed at the same time.  Nettie is a jewel

3
downstairs, - Ethel says you are very nice and cosy after you get there.  Harry says you seem "pretty happy."  Harry is funny.  I must stop writings so much nonsense and write to Marion.  Your letters are very gladly received.  We want them often, but do not lose any sleep to write.  I hope it does not trouble you so with home letters as it used to other letters.  Wilder wrote saying he had not had an answer to his letter to you and was anxious to hear.  I must say good night with much love to Azariah & Anna.
Mother
Nettie wishes me to say that her post script was a fraud.

P.S. I have just read Mater's part of this letter and wish to add to it again.  I darn all the stockings, mend all the clothes, wash dishes, take care of Mayo, make all the beds and do all the sweeping.  This is intended for a fraud. Net
Dear Ann
You were mean to say what you did about me when I told you my postscript was a fraud.  I feel insulted.  The teachers read a list of names of people from all the classes to sing at Commencement and mine wasn't there.  I'm mad. Very mad.  You better come home and comfort me, hadn't you? ((unclear)) has said things to at least three girls.  "Has your sister Annie got back yet?" or "Where is your sister Annie" "Oh she was at home for a while but she went to Oberlin to live with Mr. Root"  I heard stories very like this from three girls.  You will a stop put to it?  I hope you will not take the scolding Mother gave you greatly  to heart as Kaiser says I lead a lovely and solitary life at ([Prescot))  Such lives lead to suicide you know.  Take warning and return to  Yours Truly N.P.M.
[Mater]] wants me to apologise for the blot I made it
This signing is according to Miss Lyon's method. she is sick now so I'm good & keep her commandments.

Sunday, May 22nd 1887
My very dear Anna,
We did not intend to abuse you.  We severally and singly beg and implore your pardon.  I left if for your Father to write:  He the same for me.  How have you lived today.  I came out in my old muslin after dinner but when this delightful shower poured down upon us.  I changed for a thicker gown. The children are quarrelling. They spent the whole of yesterday out doors and the heat almost used

them up.  Eliab and Isaac Jr. much crosser than two sticks this morning.  Isaac Jr has not regained his appetite but his eyes have wonderfully improved.  The Father, Nettie, Ralph & Mayo attended church this morning, & myself went to S.S.  We have a little coal oil stove from what like Mrs. ((unclear)) We stoved our beans over it today and did not burn them.  We shall like it much in hot weather.  
I have just returned from preparing the infants supper of bread, milk & jelly.  Nettie is with them.  She and I am talking of going to hear Miss Edwards

at the Opera House this evening.  Azariah I wonder if you can not do something for Charlie Cushing.  He has apparently deserted S.S.  You know he was very much interested and almost made up his mind to be a Christian.  We must get hold of him, and I know he liked you and perhaps in some way he can be reached by you.  My beloved children I must-say good night.  I fear that Annie did not sufficiently convey my thanks or accept them for herself for the kindness and thoughtfulness of ((unclear)) of you during our measly quarrel.  Please to do so. Mother

Wednesday Feb 23rd 1887
Dear Azariah,
I feel that I was not decided at all in my views in regard to those rooms, and I hope that I did not impress you as liking them so well, that it will be a great disappointment to you if I declare that I do not believe in them.  Aunt Mallie helped me yesterday in my decision though I had found out before that stairs and woman's back were not made to go together. Anna's back is her week spot and the more I have thought about it, the more I am afreaid to have her take those rooms.  On many accounts I think it would be very pleasant for you both but in the end I do not believe it will be economy. I wish me more able to start you in a little home of your own fir I do not believe in renting or boarding, but can you not do as John Leadingham thinks of doing - buy a house on time. Furnish only a couple of rooms and take your dinners out till Anna gets use to things. Aunt Mallie who tried living on third floor in Washington says it will use Anna up to live

up stairs and do nothing. Much quicker if she tries to do work. The more I think of it I agree with you her. I am sorry I did not say so when there, but the rooms were pleasant and you gave us time to decide.  I can not write; we wish we could see you. Some less than fifty children have helped me with this letter. Yours most sincerely  Hattie H. Metcalf
This in is poor very much.

Elyria Ohio
July 29th, 1887
Dear Anna and Azariah, Your letter at hand this morning: and very interesting to us. I am glad you enjoy riding about that beautiful country. If you rode to Martinsville did you call upon or enquire after the Whipples who formerly lived in our yard. The old Mother is dead, but the boys I think both live there, and I have heard good reports of them. You ought to go over to see Uncle George and his folks. Marion we here from occasionally. One letter this morning.  She seems to be enjoying her geological excursions unclear considerable. She complains

It is very warm weather there. One excursion was to Westfield Hog's back, a sort of geological curiosity which I resided once most forty yrs ago. Today she expected to excursion to Niagara Falls. We have some company. Tuesday Prof F.H. Foster and Will unclear walked over from Oberlin early in the cool morning, staid here all day, and walked back in Evening. Grace Ethel returned from Amherst where she resided several days, on Wednesday morning.  The? unclear two Benedict girls came from Wellington, dining over, to visit Ethel. Today they with Harlan Ethel Harlan and Nettie have gone to the Lake with a big carriage to see the B???.  John did not go, having his sermons to finish. I suppose having been hindered by Prof Foster unclear

We had ice cream for supper last night. All the family unclear Ralph with the exception of myself to prayer meeting last night. I do not know whether the Miss Benedict's return tomorrow to Wellington or not.  Mrs. Savage is making the small boys some clothes. She hopes to get through soon.  I must write a unclear to Marion. Flo was here with her Edith Eastwood yesterday and staid quite a while. She was pleased with the small boys and enjoyed herself much.  Yours with love to both, Mother.

Elyria, Oct. 23, 1887
My dear Children
What a terrible wind this is. I do not like to hear it, but we did like to see the boys when they came about dark. The wind blew threw right along. We feel much broken up this season with so few of our children around us.  We are some what lonesome because we want to see the folks. I do not believe you appreciated what a fine time unclear had yesterday. We reached home 6.15. Kate was quite stirred up about the bycycles and a number of other things but she brought us home safely and we were all good natured. We think our house delightful, and you both know what we think of you all.

the unclear. We want to come again but fear the roads will be too muddy to drive over. I did not see enough of you people to tell you anything. The Father-man utterly refuses to listen to a proposition to go away from home even for the sake of hearing Dr. Parker. He says he is too old a man andit is too hard work and he just wont. We thank you much for thinking of the "skeme". I will come over and stay all night sometime. See if I don't. I am anxious to hear about the pie.  Was it good in all respects. I will send you some buter when I send the boys' clean clothes. I shall send but a little at a time as you eat so little, much will not keep well.  Don't buy any more.  Our cows are doing better and we can make enough butter for both of us. We did not think they would continue to give so much milk.

We have considerable butter ahead and shall be only too glad to furnish you.  For the past two weeks we have just gained. Our family is so small. Kepp your cloth wet in salt waer. Do not let it dry. I would put a plate over any crock. Ded we eat up all your cookies? I fear we did . I have a leg of mutton and a beef's heart to cook to morrow would like to divide with you. There come the children from Church. Here we have talked in the bed room for more than an hour and I must begin as usual to send them out. If I send a jar of butter by the boys as I may, if we can get it in the Satchel you had better put some salt on the cloth and then pour a little water on, to dissolve it. Butter will keep better with brine over it. Yours with love, Mother.

November 7, 1887. My dear Anne,
Shall we all get down on our knees and crawl under the table, to show our sorrow for not writing to you sooner? The father man was very busy last week selling the milk.  The papers were made out and the cash received Friday so that your news from Mrs. Levias was  a little premature though correct to a certain extent. We have laid up flour for a year and much feed for cattle. I am glad they have sold, but I do not like to have Charley leave us. I do not know that he intends to do so but Wilder wants him to come out West and I suppose that is the proper place for young men.  I fear that we shall be very  lonesome if all our big children leave us. The small boy have colds. Mayo coughed one night and Ralph coughed continuously yesterday.  He staid at home all day. To night Ba is at it. Tuesday eve. I was too sleepy last night to write. Can you not come over to our Missionary Meeting Thursday

at 2 P.M. Miss May Williams sends you a special invitation.  Mrs. Capron is very interesting it is said. Ely is coughing tonight. I presume I shall have to grease him and put on a silk handkerchief. I worked with well Ba last night You may buy your sugar and molasses, but we wanted to set you up at first. Here after if it troubles you, you may pay for them. How does your butter hold out? My recipes were very crude and hastily written. A very quiet election. The father voted the Anti Saloon Republican ticket. It is fine to have him at home to supper and Charley at dinner. Why don't you people write to Marion and Ethel you must find time.  A letter from Marion today asks about you. Come over Thursday. Can your family come Sunday? Good night with love to all, Mother

Elyria, Nov 15th 1887
My dear Anna,
Baby has teased me all the morning to "write a letter to Anna to tell her she had better come."  He could not go to sleep for a long time because of this letter. He is upstairs in the South room. His father brought him up this morning covered all over with a blanket. We are having our room painted. The doctor said this morning that he was doing well but for two or three days he will gain slowly. Come and stay over Sunday any way unclear, you and unclear and support the Y.P.S.C.E. Urging as much as possible.

Nettie has added her write. Ba - is quite exercised and is anxious to have this letter go. If you write him a letter it will do him good. Do not feel that you must obey his commands. We shoulld all be glad to see you, but know that you are quite busy with home and library cares. Mrs. Savage takes much care of him and just now he is good.  In a few days when he wants things it will be difficult to always please him. Yours with love, Mother

Thursday 3 P.M. Dec. 13 - 1887
My dear Anna,
I am compelled to write this to you to escape persecution. Eliab 2nd has bugged me all day to write to you that he is sick. He says I wrote to you when baby was sick and he has really been afraid he would get well before I wrote. He was taken sick with vomiting in school yesterday and I think he had a slight chill. The father was afraid he might be coming down with scarlet fever from symptoms so sent for the doctor, but it seems to be only a hard cold and some stomach trouble.  He has not vomited since morning and I dressed him about eleven this fore noon and now he seems quite happy. He has coughed very hard for two or three nights. But his cough is loose now. Mrs. Savage has not been here for two days. Mrs. Roe is quite dangerously ill and she is

with her. How did you get home with your groceries.  How is the butter. I believe you owe $2.73. Will you take Nettie's concert ticket out of that. I have taken out the 40 cents I owe. Wilder and Mary are supposed to reach Wellington to day.  Edith was over to see if you were full for tomorrow night.  She goes to Annie Leadingham's   but wanted to find a place for Anna Monroe.  Your father told her you were full.  I hardly think Wilder and Mary will be over to the concert. They go back to Lawrence the first of January. 
They do not get to Wellington till sometime today, and Wilder has hired out in Lawrence to commence work Jan 1st at $1800.00 per year. and leaving him opportunity to attend to his own land business besides.  Perhaps it will suggest itself to your mind, why Eliab is so anxious for you to know of illness. He wants to here from you. Hastily, Mother.

Dec. 27, 1887
Dear Anna
Reached house in safety and rode up from P.O. with aunt Albina. She found the specimen copy of "Wide Awake" but Nettie thinks she could make a pretty thing for Mary. The pictures are on both sides of the page in some cases which is bad.  I wil take that other book I brought home ifyou will please pay 73 cents for it to Mr. Chapman. I will give it to Mary. Nettie likes the "Picture

Gallery for her present. I have brought Mayo's copy of Wide Awake for 5 cents. In haste Mother  
I will pay you the 75 cents when I see you.

Feb. 5. 1888
Dear Children-
I owe you people 75 cents please not to forget it as I have deduct it from what you owe us.  We are as usual. We three us, Nettie, Father, and I have been to church. The walks so icy that we came home in the road.  Sleighing seems good. I can tell our news, so will say good night and snd much love. Take are of yourselves. Return your calls. Make time to be good children. Come home when you can. Mother. 
unclear my Junior Ex.Spurt.  Should I make a goose of myself and cause the unclear to retire? The mater's "children" cause me to remember  The p's applied to Hal and I. Mater's sick

I wish to correct a mistake of Nette's 'I am not mad but soon shall be."  Oh, this is wrong. I am not sick. I did have sick headache Monday night but I have been to church twice to day and taught my class so you see her mistake.

Thursday Mch. 29th 1888
Dear Children,
I have felt some what guilty ever since I came from Oberlin and left two raging ill-behaved boys to trouble and vex you. I thought it was considerable when I was there. They had a very nice time and have often remarked since that they wished they were at Oberlin. They told me as soon as they came that Anna asked then to come again. That Mr. Root was not there so did not ask them.  It was quite funny to hear them.  P.H. Boyerton is our next Mayor. I knew I had more excuse for coming home Tuesday noon that I told you. Nette had a part in the young Ladies' Mission circle "Seven times two".  I was all alone Tues. eve. till nine o'clock.  I knew I must be at home that evening and could not remember the principal reason.  I had a good restful time as I always do at your home.  Remember you are to

come over the first Sunday you can get away. I hope Azariah will really try and rest some this vacation. It is necessary. How is your cold? I must go to work. With much love in great haste, Mother.
I will send two quarts of John's butter just received. He sent ten pages but this is the part you will care for. Please return the same.

June 10th 1888
Dear Azariah,-
Do you suppose you need a little motherly advice? You live eight miles from the paternal mansion and have not been near if for six weeks. I fear you are not taking good care of yourself. You must not use your head so much with out relaxation.  I very much want to come and see what you and Anna are doing but can not get away from home. Take care of yourselves. Yours with love, Mother.

Sept. 29, 1888
My dear Anna,
Once we had such a daughter also a son Azariah but not one word have we heard from them personally for days.  You are well I hope.  D you go to the Board metting?  How does your family prosper? Come and see us when you can. Cant you come some morning and stay till the afternoon train. I want to much see you.  Love much of it to two both of you, Mother.

Mrs. Anna Mayo Stevens Metcalf
Azariah Smith Root
No 28 North Prof. Street
Oberlin.

Oct. 6th 1888
Dear People,
I hesitated after writing the first work and thought to whom shall this go. There are A. and A. who owe me a letter. There is Harl in the same condition also Ethel. I believe Harry has written and really ought to have a letter but I will be impartial. I rather wanted to be in Oberlin to morrow as a I suppose you will have some of the A.B.C.F.M. to preach to you.
I wish you could all have gone Thursday night. The Father was enthusiastic over Dr. unclear address.  I wonder if he came to Oberlin. Were you people  who went Wednesday some what fatigued?
It was too bad for Anna to wait two hours at the depot when I wanted to talk with her. Can you take me in when I come, if. I o come to O. next week or is

Prof Smith there?  Lizzie goes home Wed. or Thursday so that I may not come. Harry your letter was very good. They should come promptly every week. Indian Summer does not come till after a good hard frost, generally in November. How did you come out on the debate. I fear you do not keep up with the political  news, not to know anything about the Mills bill. I think Ethel quitke successful in getting onto the choir.  Are you also in the choir? Come over to this region and we will give you some grapes. Those that do not ripen will jell perhaps. Some apples are picked, just a few. The weather has not been faborable for such work of late especially yesterday and today. Some tomatoes picked today. Letter from St Louis this week. I am to bed going, Yours with love, Mother.

Oct. 14, 1888.
My dear Anna,
It is with great pleasure that we peruse your letter. It has been so long since you have written home. I was sorry not to be with you last week but I was prevented. Lizzie went away Thursday mornng and Sarah wanted me to spend Wednesday with her as that was the only time we three were together. Also, I am having my annual cold and fell very dull and stupid.  Other reasons I could give but these are enough.  I hope to live long enough and feel well enough to spend many pleasant visits with you, but not just now. I wish I could help you mind and help you in other ways. I have always anticipated helping you so much but have not done anythink as I have hoped. Well, never

mind it is all right or it would not be. We are glad to see Harry, and with you people could spend a Sabbath with us. It is bad to be so near and yet so far. I am afraid you tired yourself  out last week. Take care of yourself and take life easy.  You don't have to live this life but once. Come when you can, write when you can. Do not worry.  Do not hurry get not tired. Let some things go. Come and make quince jelly this week. Yours with love, A and A, Mother.
Father thinks of going to Rochester Tues. night to Cleveland Conference. Come and stay all night with me and we will make jelly. The folks can do with out you one day. They would have to if you were sick.

Jan 4th 1889. My dear Anna,- Had I not feared that the rough roads would shake me to pieces, I should have come with Marion this morning. Marion told us of Edith's desire to stay with you and I will very hastily say any little say. I do not want you to have extra care that will worry you, but if Miss Stanley can come and help you, it seems to me that it will really be easier for you.  She is so nice and capable. I can see that boarders are not so pleasant as to be alone, but it will be much

more profitable to have two instead of one, and with Miss Stanley to take so much care off your shoulders you will have more time for the library. Am I correct in my quarts. Marion is in haste as it is nearly time for consecration meeting to which she and Nette will so hie so I must say good night with much love, Mother. Do not do this if it is going to make you worry. It is wicked.

Feb. 17, 1889
Dear Annie, We heard that you and Azariah came near coming home. I wish you could and would. How do you do? These people who come from your house seem to know little about you who sty at home. We are a usual and of course enjoyed the valentines much. The small boys have valentines for Annie but we hardly thought them worth the postage but will send with this.

Mary came Monday and was very welcome. Things have changed in appearance since her return. That molasses we made you pay 90 cents for we will all right.  I know now that is only a gallon or five qt jug. Is it getting empty? Do you take care of yourself? Harl says that Azariah is very busy. Ethel writes as though she was enjoying herself exceedingly. She says you are jolly family and all funny. Nette does not think we are very jolly, but we are noisy. I suppose we shall have to be vaccinated if the children continue in school.

2
Come and see us some day. Can you not come on the ten o'clock train some day and stay till five o'clock? Father man is reading to me and I may be a little mixed in my composition of this epistle. Has Marion told you, she is having the Murry's and wants letters. We have written nine to her since last Sunday, I must say good night. Love to both of you two, take of each other and do not get too tired. Mother.  
These valentines were ready to send the 14th but Mayo wanted to send too but he has not furnished his yet. He has three hands.
Right hand, Left hand and a little behind hand.

March 15, 1889
Dear Annie, I am going to rebel and feel that I know still less than I do know, if you tell Ethel she cannot learn about house work at home. I have always know that I am not a success at keeping house. I think every one of you girls far my superior in many of the details, but I will confess that I never like it and know only what I was obliged to learn until I was married. Family cares came thick and fast

not being strong. I lost my ambition and as a natural consequence my house looks like destruction or would if I had not had you, and then Nette to lift the burden. I like house work exceedingly now, and I fear break the tenth commandment, for I do covet health and strength like Mary's for instance. Now you are some what in my condition. You have not been well for years or rather not strong. You also disliked house work when a girl and you think you know but little about it, but I know that you do know.

2
and I think you learned some of it at home perhaps more by practice in your own house. Ethel is strong. She seems willing and anxious to learn. I beleive she will do it. I think she can do it here and it rather troubles me to have any feeling of doubt. I think there is a great change in Ethel. I have noticed it this year. Her present surroundings, of an unselfish sister and brother A. and Mary Stanley are doing her good.  She is beginning to appreciae them more and more. It does me good to see it. I believe it will do you and Azariah good to be told that she appreciates you. I think that Nette is the

same school will develop in to a true woman.  It is in her. I hope your health and strength will hold out so that these younger ones may all come under the same influence.  You are doing good work. Now my beloved Anna I hope I have said nothing to worry or to trouble you. I have thought the subject over and see how we can arrange so that Ethel can learn many things if I am to some extent laid up. What she needs especially to learn is cooking mending and sewing generally. If Mary stays with us as I

3
hope she will. We can fix things well. God bless and keep you. Be careful Anna of yourself. You did me good you cooked so well the other day. I believe if you are careful you will henceforth be a stronger woman. With much love to both Mother.

Elyria 8.25 P.M. Sept 17, '89
My dear Anna, Your letter just received. Ethel forgot to deliver or I should have sent a line by Harry. I think you had better take a student girl if she comes along. I have written to Carrie but fear she will be unable to come very soon Sarah says that the brother for whom she keeps house is to be married this fall but she does not know just when and Carrie will have to stay till after the wedding.  I hope to hear from Carrie soon but as I do not know her address I had be to send my letter to her home and her people will deliver. We had a good ride Saturday only the visit was all too short. I wanted to stay. Ba was a good boy. I hope Nette will not be home sick and that she will make frequent visits to 28 N. Prof. Street.

I am sorry the news papers were not remembered. Next time we will try and not be in such haste. We have made 25 glasses and three bowls of apple jelly to day. You are to have some. I must to bed go. Be good and happy both two of you. If you want me send for me. Yours with love, Mother. If we should desire to write to Nette shall we send the letter to Spear Library.

Oct. 1 1889
Dear Anna, - How do you and the blessed ba- do? I intended to write last night but his small Keyes objected so I obediently stopped. Train your boy better. Carrie Bechlet was in yesterday. She goes to Chicago. Lucy's woman won't come to you. I think Keyes and I will come and spend the winter. What wages will

you pay a woman with a baby thrown in? I want to come over but the roads are heavy. Perhaps I will come Friday. Azariah please write us for Anna. Anna be very careful. You can not be too careful. Ba- will be happier and stronger if you are careful. I do very exceedingly want to see you.  Nette says your ba is prettier than Keyes at his age. I expect you will have a blue day this week but never mind it is part of the progress

How is Nette and Mrs unclear and Aunt Albina. I nice letter from Harl this week. I must send this for the mail man to take. Keyes is  assisting me as you will perceive.  Make haste slowly. with much love to all and Kisses for the baby. Mother. Will write sometime when I do not have so much help.

Monday Eve. Dear Anna and Azariah, - A great burden is off my mind. I am so glad Mrs. Hoffman is with you. I came near being worried much about you. Now keep Mrs. Hof- as long as possible. Poor ba. I hope his pains have departed. I also hope you won't have to dose him any more with medicines. I have not seen Mrs. Savage since I brought her home Saturday but she said she

was very busy sewing and getting ready to come here.  I hope she will come soon. When I heard that  Mrs. H- was with you I felt like shouting Hip, hip, hurrah, Your all right now. Mary is having her vacation but when Mrs. Savage can come I shall come over to Oberlin. Have you heard from the Lorain girl? Where is Miss Turner? Did she come home? Ba- is four weeks old tomorrow. How the days go. I want to see the little fellow. They laugh at me because I want to come to Oberlin so

2. 
much. Tuesday morning. How do you do again? I did not finish last night. Remember me to Mrs. Hoffman. Continue to be happy. Much love to two both of you, Mother.

Tuesday Evening
My dear Annie,
I feel somewhat encouraged in regard to the girl question. You spoke about Ruth Smith. After I took Aunt Albina home I thought I would drive around the way and see, I had no expectations of success. Mrs Smith was the only one at home She said perhaps Ruth would go as her Father is better just now she would tell her. Ruth and May came around to see me tonight and Ruth thought she would like to try it. She says she likes you and thinks she would not be homesick. She can iron all but collars shirts & cuffs, unclear wash dishes, clean lamps sweep and do what you tell her. She has made bread but you will need to show her your way. I think she can get your meals with some showing at first. She wants to learn. I fear she has not consulted her father and he may say "No!" May, I

know wanted me to ask her instead of Ruth. She was real mean in her remarks to Ruth. Telling her she did not know how to do different things. I think it will be a good thing for Ruth and I believe she really can help some with baby. She loves babies. She would have come over tomorrow but I cannot come till Thursday, and she wants me to go with her. If you do not want her send word by Ethel tomorrow and we will not come, we will probably come on morning train Thursday if Mr. Smith and May will let her. Ruth will be here tomorrow. Mrs. Savage says take baby to bed with you. Do not get up nights with him. If he finds out that crying will make you take him up he will cry. I never get up with a baby unless he is really sick. You can put a shawl over you and sit up to change him. Mrs. Savage also says "Why don't they give celery?" She says it was not she that told you it made his head hot. She says, she told you it was not well to give it, when you were giving other medicines. She does not believe

in the other medicines. I do not know but what I shall consult with Mr. Sherwood about the small boy's sleeplessness. Ruth wanted to know what wages I asked her what she thought she could earn. If she does every thing she thinks she can earn $1.75 If you have your large articles done at the laundry, I presume $1.50 at first would do. It might be well to have your dinners brought up for a week or so till she has the run of things. At the depot I heard of a colored girl that wants a place. She has worked at Mr Olds Pleasant Street, her home is on East Lorain. Her name I think is Coles or something like it. I hope you will all sleep well. Let me hear from you tomorrow, I must to bed. 
Yours with much love,
Mother

Elyria October 11, 1889
My dear Annie,
I suppose you are anxious to hear from me. Mrs. Lyons cannot come but Miss Turner will be there Tuesday. If the roads are good I shall bring her over and take Mrs. Savage back. Otherwise I shall try and come with her on the train. I coaxed hard. She had just taken an agency for a book. "Life and Letters of Roscoe Conklin" and thought it would not do to put it off. She wants to canvass Oberlin and decided that after the two weeks nursing She might continue to stay with you if you were willing to have her help nights & mornings. I like her quite well & Aunt Anna says Mrs Herman Ely liked her. Mr Lirsch wanted her to nurse his two boys who are sick with Typhoid fever but she did not want to take the care of fever patients. Do no worry. In great haste. Mother.

Oct. 20 1889
My dear Anna, --
How has the day gone with you? I am anxious to hear from you. Can you not write us a postal often, I wish I could run in more often but you must send us word often. If I could find you a real good girl I should try and come over with Keyes for a few days and help you take care of your baby while the girl helped take care of Keyes.

You are somewhat acquainted with Eliab's characteristics. He is very slow to mind. He learned the fourth commandment last week. This is the way he had it at first "Six days shalt thou linger etc. I must to bed go. With much love and good wishes, Mother. 
Kiss Francis for his Grandmother Ike Steve's version of the Lord's prayer may amuse you, "Thy kingdom come, it shall be done on earth as it is in heaven." Send word on the noon train, I will send postal for fear you have none in the house. Have Nette put it in the office,

Monday morn.
My dear Annie,
Your letter came Saturday evening. Harry thinks of coming home nights. -- the little boys are all in school except Ba- so that he can study where he pleases until 4 o'clock then he can go into the South Room upstairs. He may change his mind after trying it and stay with you. Don't hurry about your house & do not put up a bedstead till you get the one that is to stay put-up. Harl will not be

there before Monday of next week. I hope you are not waiting for this. I might have written this and sent it to the Post yesterday but it was Sunday. We are well and hope you have entirely recovered from your home trip of a week ago. I was pretty well used up for the rest of that day. Celia? Nelson Butler is visiting at her father's & I must try & get there this afternoon. I can not write more because Isaac Jr. helps too much in the wrong direction. At present he is Romeo & requires much notice. He also has a knack of leaving his mark on my

letter. I shall try and come over to see you this week. Letters from Marion & Ethel came the last of the week, telling of their safe arrival. Now do not worry about things. If it is going to be a worry to you to have Harl & Harry with you I shall object to their being with you. "Be not therefore anxious for the morrow: for the morrow will be anxious for itself." Take care of yourselves & do excuse this ill-written epistle. If you were here you could see the reason why. With much love to all two of you. Mother

My dear Annie,-
I have intended to write to you for days but time is limited Rachel came back Wednesday night and I have been petting my cold most of the time since. I did really mean to get over and see you this week but the chances are that I shall wait until ______. What think you of my Columbus trip. If Mrs. Savage is here can it be done? Would it be too great a favor to ask of you that small Isaac

stay with you for a day or so at that time? I know you are busy and I feel that it is putting an additional burden upon you. We have not heard a word from you for a long time. Can you not come for over Sunday. Father is waiting so I must close this scribble. Come just as often as you possibly can. It will do Azziah good to hear some of our noise & it will do us quantities of good to see all two, both of you. Much love, Mother. 
How do you like your roomers. Are they noisy. How goes the furnace.

Take Notice. Read the last sheet first if you are short of time. 
Nov. 14, 1889
My dear Annie,
I told Mrs. Savage your dire extremity. We have all laughed over the girl episode. Aunt Mallie was here with Aunt Anna this afternoon. She was greatly surprised at the girls' leaving. Never knew a North Amherst girl to do such a thing before. I will tell you Mrs. Savage' remarks about coming over. If she had nothing to do and was at home she should be

glad to come, but she feels that she can not afford to come without charging, and she says she should not feel like charging you what she feels her time is worth. She knows you are poor that you have been to great expense. Perhaps she would object to my telling all this. I told her to go as far as we are concerned. She has $4.80 a week here but does not come till eight in the morning. She proposed to go down and see Mrs Lyons this evening. Perhaps she would come for a little while at a reasonable price. Mrs Savage thinks she

Sunday Eve Nov. 17,
My dear Anna,
Nette thinks you remarked that you do not want to try another girl. I went down to see her Mother yesterday and requested her to send the girl to me when she came to town. Her Mother expects she is to go to you but I can find her a place I think if you think best not to take her. I will pass judgement upon her when she comes. If I like

her had I not better keep her? She has worked at a Mr. Tenney's in Lorain. Is there a Mr. Tenney in Lorain a relative to Mrs. Brand? Just write a few lines to tell about things. Hastily
Mother.

My dear Azariah,
I am a little troubled in spirit for fear you think I am unsympathetic and heartless. I scolded you because you were nervous, but I feared that Anna seeing you worried would worry more, and I think it would be a great help to her if you do not show your worry. You have a beautiful boy and he is growing, we all are anxious that he and Anna should have the best of care

It has troubled me much that things are as they are. I can see that Mrs Turner is not like Mrs. Savage, but Mrs Savage had a talk with her and she says she likes her, and she believes in her. She has common sense and though evidently awkward is not a failure. I have a scheme, can you not get Mrs. Hofner to look in upon you once a day, or is she too far away? I want to be over there very much, and shall come as much as possible anytime when you want me. Meanwhile Keep up a good heart; Yours with love,
Mother.

My dear Anna,
My dear I think I said I would not write you again but I will. I may not be able to get to Oberlin the forepart of the week as I expected Circumstances over which I have no control may prevent; I am looking into the girl question. Do not worry things will be all right. -Do not give up the use of fruit because of baby's stomach
I think it is necessary for you and him too. It is nine o'clock and I must to bed. I intended to write more. Yours with much love, Mother.

Monday Eve
To the dear Oberlin Children,
This is a company letter but especially I would ask Harl and Harry what has become of your soiled clothes? We have had none for two or three weeks. To Anna & Azaniah I would say that I appreciate the trouble & care that small Isaac was to you and fear that you lost two nights' rest. I thank you for your goodness. We are as usual. The Father thinks of going to Chicago tomorrow morning, to the reunion of his College Society. Will be gone till Friday I hope after his return to come and see you. I will write a letter sometime. How goes house work Anna? Where do you board? Tell us all about yourselves. 
Mother.
I have just seen Harl's letter. You might try the Chinaman for a while on shirts collars & cuffs and see how he
