does. But where are your handkerchiefs, nightshirts etc etc I should think you would need some clean ones.

My dear Anna, --
You sent too much cash I return $.50 and also some eggs. I had a very nice time and I think you did one good while at Oberlin. I hope you did not tire yourself all out as that we can not come again. We enjoy Harry's visit much and the small boys abuse him to their hearts desire. In spite of the good influence surrounding Ralph at Oberlin it did not follow him. War was declared immediately on his return an continues more or less unto this day. Hastily/Mother.
As economists I advise you not to trade much with the foregoing writer. It seems she carried over five lbs of butter, and charged you for seven. I am glad her conscience compels her to make unclear partial restitution. This is a base insinuation. I said there were 5 1/2 lbs. butter as Mrs. Savage took 2 lbs. We are

Tues. afternoon My dear Anna, I was too cross to write last night. It was too warm for this time of year to make one happy. The father man went to Chi- this morning and it seems a great event to have him away. I hope he will have a good time. I do not think he will enjoy the Society meeting so much as he will to see the city. I expect E.W. went with him. He is to go to Morrison I had

a good time at Columbus but was about used up when I came home. I had a sick head ache that night I came home which is some excuse for my not knowing anything when I saw you at the train. I must write to Marion & Ethel so can write no more to you. Come over when you can. Yours with love, Mother.

Saturday morning
My dear Anna,--
I send by Nettie 3 lbs butter I have intended to come over some day all the week but the weather has been too cold, I did not dare venture out. Harry's coat could not be well mended as I could find nothing like it in the house & so I just darned it down. Mrs. Savage has not been here since that Saturday you came. Do not coax Nettie to stay as she has not time. When the weather moderates you may expect me. Yours with love, Mother.

April 21, 1890.
My dear Anna,
Your note received. I have been intending to write but have found no time. I have enquired once for the Stockings at Baldwin's and sent down last week, but they had not come. They said they would write to find out the reason they did not send them. Francis' foot must have grown as the shoes were long enough when made. Salt-pork fat is the nicest of any fat for all purposes. I always like to save every bit of it. You need not salt the food you put it in. Nettie says the board at her new boarding place is very fine, better than where she boarded last. Do not feed your boarders too high. I am coming over to see you sometime but I made up my mind when I was over there that I never would come to Oberlin again, until the roads were better. I never

had such a shaking in my life, going to the depot was worse than when we went up to your house. I want to see Francis as well as the rest of you. Does your sewing progress? I must stop and mend pants for fear Keyes will awake. Yours with love, Mother.
Is there anything here, or anywhere in this vicinity, that you want brought over to Oberlin? I, Grandfather Metcalf, want to see my grandson. So I am going to Oberlin--sometime. I have an excuse to carry over a barrel of sugar I promised to carry over last fall as soon as the roads were decently good. They are getting so now.

June 10, 1890
My dear Annie,
Before making beds this beautiful morning I will write a line to you "chillins." We are well as usual and happy. The weather is delightful. Yesterday E.W. lent us Tom horse for the day and we enjoyed the rides much especially Keyes who was afraid at first but soon recovered and objected to being taken from the carriage We were very glad to learn that you were not all used up entirely when you reached home. We are anxious to know whether Francis has become acclimated. Does Eastern milk agree with him? Have those other teeth come? Azariah are you attending to that foot? Do devote your time to it. I believe it is dangerous in its present condition not only to happiness and comfort but also to longevity. Anna you just keep at

him. Have him consult other physicians than a specialist in that line. Do you people continue to boil? A letter from Carrie yesterday says John left St Louis for Geneva Lake Monday night. We are very glad to hear that he has left the city without getting sick. I hope you are having delightful rides among those beautiful hills, and will be wonderfully refreshed when you return. Keyes helps me so much in this that I can stop sooner than I otherwise might. His fingers on words emphasize them. Write as often as you can. Please remember me to your father & Mother. 
Yours with love, Mother.
Marion is at Dear Isle? We have not heard from Harl.

July 30, 1890.
My dear Annie,-
It has been my intention for a number of days to answer your letter but I did not seem to get at it. We are as usual in health, but we are very exceedingly warm. I think I have not felt the heat so much this year as I did yesterday. About four o'clock yesterday afternoon Mr & Mrs Herbert Brooks, Abbie and Chrissie drove up to stay over night. This P.M. they drove over to Oberlin and we expect them back soon. I hope you are having delightful cool weather, I am glad you have a chance to ride so much. I am sorry that Azaniah has not attended to his foot. Our church is not ready yet for occupancy and I fear will not be for a couple more Sundays. Keyes has eleven teeth and the other is expected every day. then I hope he will

rest till Sept. The men and three small boys went to the Lake last week. I do not think I shall try to go this summer though the Uncle E.W. has invited me to go in his delightfully easy carriage. Will & Carrie are here but I have just seen Carrie to shake hands. Mrs Gaylord and her Rollo & Gladys are still here. Grace is very miserable and has gone to Conn. to her Grandfather's. Uncle Dr. is very feeble, and today Aunt Anna has neuralgia. We look for Marion next week and perhaps John & Carrie. 
When do you people expect to get home. If Francis should have the measles I should not worry. I would not want to expose him purposely, especially while he is teething, but babies generally have them light. I hope he has not been exposed for it would make it hard for you. I supposed you were down stairs I thought Mr & Mrs Pool's rooms were down stairs. Going up and down stairs is hard work with a baby, Francis is ten months old. What a big baby he is getting to be.

2
Does he lose flesh any? 
Lu Livers Shepard has a baby five months old that I believe is heavier than your baby was at that age. He is a big fellow. Lillie Sutcliff has a very bright looking baby. It is nine o'clock and those people have not come. I am a good mind to go to bed. I am so warm & tired I cannot write a decent letter. I can think of nothing to say. Write often even though you have time but for a few words. Do get all the sleep possible. Yours with love, Mother. 
Do not try to sew but sleep and rest instead while baby will let you.We are having some exceedingly warm weather. But in spite of it we are all quite well. The young Keyes did seem to suffer some with his teeth, but I think he is about through with it now. And he seems to enjoy life about as well as anyone. The Mother has some pains in her left arm and shoulder, and it tires her to write much.

Aug. 11. 1890

My dear Annie,

   Your welcome letter came in time but we had looked for it some days. I intended to write yesterday but Keyes did not feel as happy as usual and I had not the time. Our last spell of hot weather was pretty hard on him and though we do not call him sick, he is not well. He looks peaked. He has his twelve teeth. The Waite baby has been very sick also the Crosier baby & Lamberton baby but they are all getting better. We have had two or three cooler days, and they are delightful. We seem to keep quite comfortable as a whole. It seems as though I never felt the heat as I did those warm days.

John came Saturday night and has gone to Oberlin to day house hunting. Carrie comes in a week or so.

We have not seen Mary Wilder yet. She is not very well, and her Father has been very sick. Have you heard any particulars of Mrs. Frost's sickness and death? We heard it was a sudden death.- Sick but a few days. A letter from Marion says she will not be at home for a week or so. She expects to see you on her way home. Francis keeps well, I hope. I think of nothing to do for heat-rash but to sponge him off in warm water. Keys was in the same condition and I sponged him off every night - in real warm water, he enjoyed it so much.
The clock strikes nine and I must to bed. I have been about ten minutes writing this scrawl i e my apology.
Azariah I am not satisfied about the toe I went you to consult physicians. be sure and do so. Your vacation is half gone and your toe is not cured. Anne I want you to have a kind girl I believe you need one. A competent one. Then if Ethel should come to Oberlin she

Tuesday P.M.
could board with you, and room with Nette. I do not think the girls ought to be there unless you have help. I do not know what Ethel is to do We cannot tell til we consult Marion.

Nette thinks Miss Phelps has not the time to help much. How is it? Does she do much and do it decently? Do not take the trouble to answer these questions unless you want to. I am perhaps saucy to ask them. I presume you could get Rachel Smith if you want her.

You know her disagreeable points.
Her only recommendation is cleanliness. That counts, but if you could get one other girl I think you would be more comfortable. I forgot Rachel is also careful about washing. She is really economical. I do not want to make you worry but I do want you to have enough help so that you will not kill yourself. I suppose Miss Phelps could get another place.

I must stop all this. Keyes as you perceive is assisting. Never mind what I say. I do not intend to advise but do it more than I ought. You know best - what you want and must act accordingly.

Radul is at home now, and I thought if you wanted her perhaps you could get her by speaking now, is my excuse for all this nonsense. Keyes is unhappy and I must stop. Write soon and take care of yourselves.                                            Yours with- love
                                                                                                      Mother.

Rachel would not be much help with the baby but she can sew some I think. If you had rather not have Nette just say so.

July 2, 1891
My dearly beloved Anna, -  I wish to thank you very much for your very great kindness to Florence Bullock. I did not intend she should make you so much of a visit and I feel as though I had almost imposed upon your good nature. She is here this afternoon, came to thank me (to whom no thanks are due). She says she had the best time in Oberlin she has had in Ohio. You must have treated her royally.  Now may I say a few words about Rachel. I feel that it is

too much for your peace of mind to have her there in her sour state of mind.  You are not obliged to have her if she is saucy and cross all the time. I did not know she was so much so, till Marin told me so. She is to be pitied poor thing and I am sorry for her but you ought not be troubled with her.   Why not have a good talk with her before she goes away, tell her if she does not feel happy with you she had better go else where not come back.  The right one will come after a time. I am seriously thinking of taking baby and camping down on you  some time this summer. I believe we might have
a good restful time. What think you? I should much like to see you. Are you very exceedingly tired? I must finish my copying my missionary paper which I read tomorrow.   Yours with love,  Mother?

Dec 22, 1892  My dear Anna, The reception at Mrs. Ely's is a grand crush, evidently. I judge that nearly everyone is invited. I think they must want to reunite the different factions. I have nothing to wear only what I wear everywhere, but I intend to go. Why can you not come over Wed. prepared to spend the rest of the year and until term time next year. We will try and make you comfortable though I know we have not a comfortable place for winter. but if you can be comfortable in

the boys room you are very welcome, and we shall be delighted to have you.  You. Azariah Smith Root   Anna M.S. Metcalf Root  Francis Metcalf Root  are especially invited to spend the holidays at 43 West Avenue Elyria, commencing at the least before Wednesday Dec 28th 1892, and continuing indefinitely.  Yours with love Father & Mother

Elyria March 27. 1892  My dear Anna,- It is indeed fine to have letters from you.  You are a very fine letter writer One breadth of the carpet was spoiled. The door? shows that fire has past over it. You can let the other Oberlinites read the letters sent over. It is not necessary to retrieve them as we answer them before they are sent away. I think it very nice that you can find good worthy people to help you. The father has not been real well the past week. His stomach and brain evidently out of order. also Ralph has been having a bilious attack today. I think he played too hard yesterday.  I hope to go to Glee Club tomorrow night. I want to very much.

The Father bought two tickets. Perhaps we can prevail upon him to go. Mayo, Eliab and Isaac have gone to the church to night to hear Mrs Harding. It is the tenth Anniversary of the "Little Helpers" all former members are invited. Here they come. Well! They are on their way to bed. and I must follow in their foot steps. Minnie went home Friday night to spend vacation and I do miss her. The baby is fretful somewhat. His eye teeth are troubling him, I think. He loves Minnie and will go to sleep with her quieter than with me. Things worry him more they ever did Keyes. I fear he is going to have the kind of disposition that Ralph and Isaac have. I must to bed. Yours with love  Mother  I went to prayer meeting Thurs. first time in months.

Mar. 31 1892 My dear Anna,- Your letter, also one from each of the other girls came yesterday. I will only write a word.  We shall be pleased to welcome you home Saturday. We are always greatly pleased when any of you can come home. The Father man is sick. He did not take care of himself last week and so is not so well. He is in bed since yesterday. He was going down town yesterday morning but Uncle E.W. came prior then and soaked his feet and put him to bed.  The Doctor and Uncle E.W. were here twice in order to keep him in bed they said. They have both just gone. I think the doctor thinks father is doing well. I meant to have sent this by post man Must send by unclear Yours- Mother. What was the matter with Francis?

Elyria. Aug 3. '92 Dear Anna  Your letter came last night and the Mother wrote to you soon after the girl went away. A great strong good natured girl 19 yrs old upon whon she had based very great expectations. With Marion and Nettie she was talking of getting up before seven in the morning instead of before six, to say nothing of various other reforms and easements. She was a nice looking girl, but she had never been away from home before and she got dreadfully homesick. But -  the object of this writer is especially to affirm that the other writer, the aforesaid writer reports a slan

derous accusation against this very estimable and especially good natured and amiable family and household. I am personally tolerably well acquainted with the whole family in question and have been quite intimately associated with them during the whole time of the unpleasantness referred to. And I hereby assent with no fear or chance of contridiction that  "Cross" is a word entirely uncalled for in any authentic history of the matter. If any body has heard a cross word from any one it must have been from some very young and very immature person irritated beyond measure by excess of clothing or some other "impedimenta" in this extreme weather. I affirm that the spirit

and temper of the whole family is and has been simply saintlike and angelic. All even the young and immature aforesaid are also in a state of robust and smiling good health. Keyes stomach under too much stress of green apples and c. and c.? did rebel a little for a single do a week or mo ago. But both he and Nelson ever since eat every green and dry thing not only with impunity but with apparent advantage and improvement moral and physical. Marion says, this man's veracity is only equalled by his _______  Nelson and Keyes are very crooked. It is a lovely morning.

Aug 14. 1892  My dear Annie,- I fear you have had no word from home the past week. We enjoy your letters very much. I am so glad you are having a good restful time. It rests us to have you rest. A week ago Saturday Mrs. Clark the employment woman sent for me to tell about a sixteen year old girl who had been here last week with a theatrical troupe. Came from Sandusky as nurse to the pianists three month baby. The baby, poor thing, was cross and starved, and she thought that being "Ladies' Maid" was not so much fun after all.  They did not pay her anything. I felt sorry for the poor child and so we have tried her for a week, but she can not get up in the morning, and can not do anything properly, so she much go. She is weak in character and it troubles me to turn out into the cold world, but I fear my strength is not sufficient.  and I know I lack grace. Tomorrow, we are to have a niece of Uncle Eliab's man. She just came from Germany last week. She is supposed to be strong and bright but can not talk English. We went to the Lake yesterday in the band wagon, Ralph Fay, Marguerite and Mr E.R. Bullock of Pawtucket R.I. went with us. He is Ella Keat's brother. It was a beautiful day. We went down the Gulf road and back by way

of Lorain. Marion Florence Nettie, Nelson, and Harl went with Uncle E.W.'s folks. Wednesday. Nelson is a jolly man to take pic nicing. I taught the babies class in S.S. to day. Such little ones as Keyes, Scott Bowen, etc?. Mrs. Searles' little girl beats any child I ever saw. She is couple of months older than Keyes, and she can not sit still or keep still one whole minute, and will not mind. Francis can not begin to come any where near her in activity. I should think she would wear her mother out. I must stop and write to the Kansas boys. What girl have you engaged for Sept? How is Azariah's toe. How is his general health? I forgot to say we sent word to John Friday night and when we reached the lake Saturday, there he was ahead of us on his wheel. Politics are moving. The chances seem to be improving for Harter. Mr Johnson is supposed to be getting some what anxious. With love to all Mother.  Very glad to hear that you are really taking time and getting rested. Do so more and more I do not believe you need to watch that young man Francis all the time. He is not so deteriminedly vicious all the time as Thomas Nelson. And even he has his good points. He is amusing at a Pic Nic, and good when riding. Father.

Jan 5. 1894. My dear Anna.- I intended to have written you the day that Nette came home but as usual I put it off. I am glad your throat is better. Do you keep Hydrastis in the house. I would, and use it on the first inidication of soreness. I do not dare to be with out it. Nette told about our colored boy scheme. I think it would be a good thing and such a very good excuse to get rid of Lillie. You would not have to have him in the parlor and he would be strong enough to do whatever you need. Cleaning house and all such things. Can he wash, iron and cook. I want you to get of Lillie and it is a good chance to do so.

I must stop or I shall be late for the postman. Wilder goes to Cleveland with Uncle E.W. to day and we shall not probably see him again this time. We send John's letter which was very prompt this time. Yours with much love Mother.

July 31. 1894  My dear A. and A.- Your letter of July 29 came to day. It was good as usual. I meant to have sent you a letter to day but neglected to write it. We have a fine scheme and we are all agreed and so is Annie Leading unclear and I believe Azariah will believe with us. We want you to come home and then lend us Francis for a couple of weeks while you folks and Nettie and perhaps Marion go to Linwood or elsewhere on the shore and stay. We are alarmed for you Annie. We fear nervous prostration or some other ill to befall you if you do not have a regular rest. Now, we can take care of Francis, Ethel and I are

very anxious, so are W and N. but Ethel and I want very much to have the entire care of him. I know he will be good with us and it will do us good. It will not worry me and it does trouble me to have you feel so worried about him. If you were not tired all out you would not notice his noisy boisyiness? so much. Now is not this practical? It will be good for Francis to feel that he is only one of a good many, and we will try hard not to teach him bad morals. Other people let their children visit their grandparents why should not you. We shall be much disappointed if you do not agree to our proposition. Just think how

I went away and left five boys for Marion to Mother and we only want your one. I know it will be hard to part with him but you will be seen and it is a duty you owe to him and Azariah to keep in good health. I think I can say no more only we love you all very much lovingly Mother
The Mother has said well. She will be a good grandmother. Take her advise at once.  We have been to Lake Erie several times this summer, and know it's a better place than Middlefield. Father

Elryia, Jan. 8. 1879.  My dear Emily,- Better late than never. I expect you are brimful? of happiness over mother and baby-boy. What's his name? Should much like to see the little fellow. Have you been freezing? We have had very cold weather but I have not know about it much as I have been out but twice in a month or so. I rode over to A.H's New Years for the first time in six weeks, so you see I'm not very neighborly. We are all in usual health but have had hard colds

Harriet wrote the other page, but did not getthe opportunity to finish it. Now she sends word to you not to be too proud of your boy if he is a little older tan hers. She is willing to compare with you. Ours was born two P.M. yesterday, the 9th, weighs 8 lbs. and seems very healthy and strong, and the Mother is doing well and is very happy. Sincerely I. Metcalf

Mother's Archives
Mrs. G. H. Bullock
Pawtucket

My trip East was just what I needed I had a delightful time and am so glad I went. I came home a new person. Can not you people come visit this winter. I suppose now is the dull season with you. We should be? glad to see you. Are Florence and Edith better? I must stop as I want to write a line to Lizzie adn it grows to be near bed-time. You know what a sleepy-head I am from experiene. With much love to all upstairs and down I remain, Most sincerely yours, Hattie H. Metcalf

Watch Mr. Morison's hoarde?
Jan 18th 1887 Dear John and Harl, How is the sore throat Harl? We have seen nothing from our pen this week. We were glad to see Harry. It is cold over here so much so that I have not ever put my head out side the door this year as yet. I want to go down street and get somethings among others some stockings for you Harl. John your stockings are a fraud they are so short. You had better turn them over to some prim little fellow and have some decent length. They were not expensive you remember. Give them to some little colored urchin. I think your club is rather extravagant.

I believe you can board well at less money. How would it pay you if it keeps cold to buy a hind quarter of beef and then you would have good roasts, steaks or soups. Perhaps you could not eat it all. How many are there of you? It pays to buy by the quantity. Father is peacefully snoring as are also some of the rest and I think I had better do likewise. None of the rest of the family seem to suffer from any attack at least none of them have contracted any sickness as yet. We are comparatively happy. Don't work too hard, and do go to bed before midnight. It will pay you in the long run. Yours with love, Mother.   I would write some news if I knew any.
